moves.1. e4: I realize neither this game nor I am particularly good. I just wanted to annotate something for my own benefit.
moves.1... c5: The best response to e4 in my opinion. e5 tends to turn into an uninteresting game.
moves.2. d4: A bit unexpected, but playable. Better would be to stick to theory and play Nf3.
moves.4. Qe3 g6: Preparing to fianchetto the bishop, seems like a sound decision.
moves.5. Bb5: ? Not completely sure what this accomplishes, although it does develop a piece and applies pressure towards the king.
moves.6. Bxc6: Better to develop more pieces than to trade mindlessly.
moves.6... dxc6: Opens up a file for the queen, and later the rook. As well, keeps the pawn islands.
moves.7. e5: Slightly premature pushing of the pawn, although it does block off the bishop nicely.
moves.7... Bf5: Develops other bishop while attacking at the same time.
moves.8. Na3: Awkward way of defending the pawn.
moves.8... Qc7: Threatening the e pawn as well as making way for the rook to come through.
moves.9. Nf3: Solid move, prepares to castle, defends the pawn, develops a piece.
moves.9... O-O-O: I decide the queenside is safe for castling, and since it activates the rook at the same time, it seemed like a good move.
moves.10. Ng5: Threatening a fork that is hard to defend against.
moves.10... Nh6: I debated playing Bg6 instead, but thought the bishop would have a strong diagonal once the e pawn is gone.
moves.11. Nxf7: Blunder as far as I know.
moves.11... Nxf7 12. f4: Best way of defending the pawn.
moves.12... Bh6: Puts pressure on the f pawn.
moves.13. g3: Defends f pawn, but it didn't need defending. Castling looks less appealing after this though.
moves.13... Nxe5:
Comic relief:
The f pawn's pinned so I can take the e pawn for free! [Yes I blundered].
moves.14. Qxe5 Qd7: and the attack begins! Black still seems better after that blunder, as black has a strong bishop pair, connected rooks, and a potential attack.
moves.16. Kf2 Qxh1: White should probably resign just about here. That was a pretty big blunder.
moves.17... Qxh2+: There wasn't much white could do to prevent check and loss of pawn anyhow.
moves.18. Kf3: Probably not the best square to retreat to, although the back rank doesn't look too appealing either.
moves.18... Bg4+: !? Bishop sac. If white plays Ke3, Re8 wins queen. If Kxg4...
moves.19. Kxg4 Qh5#: Mate. I've always liked piece-sac mates. I admit this wasn't much of a game though... but interesting to analyze, as I am not so great at fast attacks.
